Explanation.name: Gbxmodel
Explanation.description:
This type of tag is used for Gearbox maps (but not Xbox) and features local nodes. When the cache file is compiled, then the compressed vertices are discarded when copied into the map.
Flags: - blend shared normals: On map compilation, vertices with the same positions have their normals linearly averaged. - parts have local nodes: Use local nodes. Geometries with local nodes are flagged as ZONER in this case. - ignore skinning: Unknown?
Note that compressed vertices can only address up to 42 nodes and cannot use local nodes.

Block.name: runtime markers
Block.description:
NOTE: This field MUST be empty for loose tags! This is populated by the markers stored in regions on cache build.
This field was originally cache only and the maximum was 256, however we define it differently than what it actually is so we can detect erroneous tags generated by HEK+ and Refinery.
This is an unfortunate limitation, and the *correct* approach is to treat it as cache only, but doing so would result in silent data loss for many years of tags due to bad tag extraction.

CharInteger.name: prev filthy part index
CharInteger.description: Defaults to 255, but its a hack how this is done

CharInteger.name: next filthy part index
CharInteger.description: Defaults to 255, but its a hack how this is done

LongInteger.name: triangle count
LongInteger.description: for triangle strips, the number of indices stored in the cache file = this + 2

LongInteger.name: triangle pointer
LongInteger.description: On Xbox: pointer to the triangle indices. On PC: offset to triangles relative to the end of the maps vertex data, but on map load, this is set to another pointer which is never read.

LongInteger.name: triangle pointer 2
LongInteger.description: On Xbox: pointer to the entry in the second parts list which points to the triangle indices. On PC: same value as the first triangle offset, and it is overwritten by a pointer on map load that is read when rendering.

CharInteger.name: local node indices
CharInteger.description: Local nodes are used to indirectly refer to a real node. So, if local nodes are used, a vertex says node #4, and local node #4 refers to node #5, then the vertex is node #5. There really doesnt seem to be any benefit to using local nodes, considering compressed vertices (which can only address 42 nodes) dont even use them. They just make the models unnecessarily more convoluted while taking up more space.
